subject: Perl and Hacktoberfest
header: A belated happy birthday to Larry Wall, who turned 70 last Friday, 27th September.

Opensource contributions season is about to start with Hacktoberfest tomorrow. It would continue the whole month, enough time for you to contribute to opensource projects. Although I have registered to be part of this year event but I doubt to have time for contribution unfortunately.

For me, I am looking forward to the most awaited event, London Perl & Raku Workshop 2024. It is happening after a long gap of 5 years. If you are planning to attend the event then I would suggest you register your details as it would help the organiser to manage the event smoothly.
There is another Perl Conference that I completely missed and it was Perl-Conf.Ru. The first Perl developers conference in Russia in four years.

entries.title: Perl-Conf.Ru
entries.text: If you missed the event then you can still checkout the event results.

entries.title: Crypt::OpenSSL::PKCS12 1.93 released to CPAN
entries.author: jonas_bromso
entries.text: The release is offering a new feature: info which can provide the user with information from the OpenSSL object being worked on.

entries.text: Part one of 2-parts series post, Makoto-san shares his experience @ TPF.

entries.title: Board Reflections: Continued Experiences with The Perl Foundation
entries.author: makoto_nozaki
entries.text: Part two and last post continued to talk about various projects handled by Makoto.

entries.title: This week in PSC (161) | 2024-09-27
entries.text: Interesting topics discussed in the last team meetup. Thank you PSC for your time and effort.

entries.title: Cloud VM performance / price comparison 2024

entries.text: Talk on the topic was presented at The Perl and Raku Conference 2024.

chapters.title: The Weekly Challenge
chapters.header: The Weekly Challenge by Mohammad Sajid Anwar will help you step out of your comfort-zone. You can even win prize money of $50 by participating in the weekly challenge. We pick one champion at the end of the month from among all of the contributors during the month, thanks to the sponsor Lance Wicks.

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Third Maximum" and "Jumbled Letters". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 289

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Closest Palindrome" and "Contiguous Block" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
entries.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 288

entries.author: andre_ploger
entries.text: Clever use of recursive approach in Perl and Go. Hope to see regular post from next week onward.
entries.title: Diving Deep: Recursive Solutions for Palindromes and Contiguous Blocks

entries.author: arne_sommer
entries.text: As always we got plenty of Raku magics, specially the debug mode. Highly recommended.
entries.title: Contiguously Closest

entries.author: dave_jacoby
entries.text: Welcome back with yet another thoroughly discussed solution. Hope to see more in coming weeks.
entries.title: Return of the Son of This Looks Like A Job For Recursion!

entries.author: jorg_sommrey
entries.text: Mathematical approach to deal with Palindrome, something I never seen before. Great work, thanks for sharing.
entries.title: Contiguous Palindromes

entries.author: laurent_rosenfeld
entries.text: Cool trick to get the job done alongwith Raku magic. Bonus, as always, we got Perl implementation too. Keep it up great work.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 288: Closest Palindrome

entries.author: luca_ferrari
entries.text: A very simple yet effective approach and easy to follow using Raku. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.
entries.title: not complete!

entries.author: luis_mochan
entries.text: Regex? I am pleasantly surprised to see the use of regex to get the Palindrome task done. You really don't want to skip. Thanks for your contribution.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 288

entries.author: matthias_muth
entries.text: Two different approaches, simple and fast. You pick your favourites. Great work.
entries.title: The Simple and the Fast

entries.author: packy_anderson
entries.text: One stop for multiple programming languages. With that we get the special of each. Keep it up great work.
entries.title: A Man, A Plan, A Canalâ€¦ PANAMA!

entries.author: peter_campbell_smith
entries.text: It is always pleasure to see how the task contributor deals with his own challenge. I must say, you will love it. Thanks for sharing.
entries.title: Nearness and contiguity

entries.author: reinier_maliepaard
entries.text: Clean and simple solution that is self explanatory. Well done.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 288

entries.author: robbie_hatley
entries.text: Breaking down complex algorithm into smaller steps lead to a readable and easy to follow solution. Great work, thanks for sharing.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge #288

entries.author: roger_bell_west
entries.text: Interesting use of FIFO queue and implementation in Raku discussed line by line, very handy to decode. Highly recommended.
entries.title: Block the Palindrome

entries.author: torgny_lyon
entries.text: Walkthrough of complex algorithm made so simple. Great work, keep it up.
entries.title: Week 288 - Closest Palindrome & Contiguous Block

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.
